items.title: Investigate utilizing native `zoneinfo` in Python 3.9+
items.body:
<!-- Checked checkbox should look like this: [x] -->
- [x] I have searched the [issues](https://github.com/sdispater/pendulum/issues) of this repo and believe that this is not a duplicate.
- [x] I have searched the [documentation](https://pendulum.eustace.io/docs/) and believe that my question is not covered.

## Feature Request

[*Support for the IANA Time Zone Database in the Standard Library*](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0615/) will be released with [Python 3.9](https://www.python.org/downloads/release/python-390rc1/) Details: https://docs.python.org/3.9/whatsnew/3.9.html#zoneinfo

> The zoneinfo module brings support for the IANA time zone database to the standard library. It adds zoneinfo.ZoneInfo, a concrete datetime.tzinfo implementation backed by the system’s time zone data.
> 
> Example:
> ```
> >>> from zoneinfo import ZoneInfo
> >>> from datetime import datetime, timedelta
> 
> >>> # Daylight saving time
> >>> dt = datetime(2020, 10, 31, 12, tzinfo=ZoneInfo("America/Los_Angeles"))
> >>> print(dt)
> 2020-10-31 12:00:00-07:00
> >>> dt.tzname()
> 'PDT'
> 
> >>> # Standard time
> >>> dt += timedelta(days=7)
> >>> print(dt)
> 2020-11-07 12:00:00-08:00
> >>> print(dt.tzname())
> PST
> ```
> As a fall-back source of data for platforms that don’t ship the IANA database, the tzdata module was released as a first-party package – distributed via PyPI and maintained by the CPython core team.

This appears to overlap with the `pytzdata` dependency also maintained by @sdispater , and could potentially be used to give a closer-to-upstream parity, when run on Python 3.9+, similar to how `fold` was introduced and is backported in Pendulum now.

What are thoughts on moving to the stdlib library for timezone implementations?

items.body:
<!--
  Hi there! Thank you for discovering and submitting an issue.

  Before you submit this; let's make sure of a few things.

-->

- [x] I have searched the [issues](https://github.com/sdispater/pendulum/issues) of this repo and believe that this is not a duplicate.

<!--
  Once those are done, if you're able to fill in the following list with your information,
  it'd be very helpful to whoever handles the issue.
-->

- **OS version and name**: Arch Linux
- **Pendulum version**: 2.1.0

## Issue
<!-- Now feel free to write your issue, but please be descriptive! Thanks again 🙌 ❤️ -->

I would expect `tzinfo` to be maintained when converting from a `pendulum.DateTime` to a `pendulum.Time`, but it is not:

```python
>>> datetime = pendulum.datetime(2020, 6, 20, tz="UTC")
>>> print(datetime.tzinfo)
Timezone('UTC')
>>> print(datetime.time().tzinfo)
None
```

items.title: Duration methods (total_days(), in_days()) return incorrect values and/or do not match docs
items.body:
- [x] I am on the [latest](https://github.com/sdispater/pendulum/releases/latest) Pendulum version.
- [x] I have searched the [issues](https://github.com/sdispater/pendulum/issues) of this repo and believe that this is not a duplicate.

- **OS version and name**:  MacOS 10.14 (running Python 3.7.2)
- **Pendulum version**: 2.1.0

## Issue
The duration methods duration.total_days() and duration.in_days() do not match expected results, and/or do not match the docs.  Since the docs seem to show an inconsistent / incorrect result (specifically for duration.in_days()), it isn't clear what the real expected behavior is. 

I was quite confused about the logic and differences between the conversion of years/months into days for a duration (still am), so I just re-created the example used in the docs in order to test my thinking.  And when doing that, I got different results to what is shown in docs.

My results below, using exact example from Pendulum docs [duration section](https://pendulum.eustace.io/docs/#properties-and-duration-methods):

```python
# I copied example from pendulum docs
>>> it = pendulum.duration(
...     years=2, months=3,
...     days=1177, seconds=7284, microseconds=1234
... ) 

>>> it.days
1997   
# seems OK... 2 * 365 days/year + 3 * 30days/month + 1177 days = 1997

>>> it.total_days()
1177.0843055698379   
# this matches result shown in docs (1177.084...)
# but result seems counter-intuitive based on name of method
# I would expect 'total_days' to be 1997.084... including days from years and months

>>> it.in_days()
1177  
# this DOES NOT match result shown in docs (docs show 1997 for it.in_days())
# but does match description of this method being truncated integer of total_days()
```

Based on description of duration.in_days() method in the docs, I would expect duration.total_days() and duration.in_days() to return same result, only with in_days() as a truncated integer as described.  That's what I actually got, but doesn't match docs.

But larger issue seems to be that both .total_days() and .in_days() return incorrect (or at least un-intuitive) results -- I would expect them to both return 1997... in this case, including the days from years and months.  (not 1177)

Seems like there is either:
A) Incorrect example in the docs  (specifically where it shows return of 1997 for .in_days() method)
B) Bug in duration.in_days() and/or duration.total_days() method, especially when including years/months in duration
C) Both A and B
D)or I'm totally missing something...

This may be related to #387 but I'm creating this as separate bug because it seems there is at least a docs issue here, and because 387 relates to total_seconds() and maybe there are drop-in compatibility constraints with built-in total_seconds() method for that one?

Thanks to the creator & contributors!

items.body:

  Before you submit this; let's make sure of a few things.
  Please make sure the following boxes are ticked if they are correct.
  If not, please try and fulfill these first.

- [x] I am on the [latest](https://github.com/sdispater/pendulum/releases/latest) Pendulum version.
- [x] I have searched the [issues](https://github.com/sdispater/pendulum/issues) of this repo and believe that this is not a duplicate.

<!--

  it'd be very helpful to whoever handles the issue.
-->

- **OS version and name**: 10.15.4 Mac OS Catalina
- **Pendulum version**: 2.1.0

## Issue
<!-- Now feel free to write your issue, but please be descriptive! Thanks again 🙌 ❤️ -->
Pendulum datetime format prints time - 12 hours
```
import pendulum
tnow = pendulum.now().astimezone(pendulum.UTC)
print(tnow)
print(tnow.format('YMMDDThhmmss'))
```
returns:
```
2020-04-06T18:29:43.054288+00:00
20200406T062943
```

items.title: parse 'Z' timezone designator in iso8601 strings as Timezone('UTC'), not Timezone('+00:00')
items.body:
Hi, thanks so much for your work on pendulum. Much better so far than other alternatives I've been using for way too long.

It appears the iso8601 timezone designator `Z` is handled inconsistently between between parsing and rendering of datetimes to/from iso8601 strings.

On rendering a UTC-datetime to an iso8601 string, the timezone will be correctly represented as `Z`. Ex:

```python
>>> pendulum.now('utc').to_iso8601_string()
'2020-02-05T20:05:37.364951Z'
```

However, on parsing an iso8601 string, `Z` is _not_ parsed as UTC... it's parsed as `Timezone('+00:00')` timezone.

```python
>>> pendulum.parse('2020-02-05T20:05:37.364951Z')
DateTime(2020, 2, 5, 20, 5, 37, 364951, tzinfo=Timezone('+00:00'))
```

This results in some inconsistencies when rendering & parsing back and forth from strings:

```python
>>> now_iso_str = pendulum.now('utc').to_iso8601_string()
>>> now_iso_str
'2020-02-05T20:48:06.814968Z'
>>> now_iso_str_2 = pendulum.parse(now_iso_str).to_iso8601_string()
>>> now_iso_str_2
'2020-02-05T20:48:06.814968+00:00'
>>> now_iso_str == now_iso_str_2
False
```

I would propose that when parsing an iso8601 string, `Z` should be parsed directly to `Timezone('UTC')` rather than to `Timezone('+00:00')`

If this sounds like a change you would be open to @sdispater , let me know and I'll prepare a PR with tests. Cheers.

items.title: DateTime should declare itself as a subclass of datetime
items.body:
Something really strange is going on

```python
>>> a = pendulum.now()
>>> a.__class__.__bases__
(<type 'datetime.datetime'>, <class 'pendulum.date.Date'>)
>>> isinstance(a, datetime.datetime)
False
```

Surely `isinstance` should return `True` here?!

items.title: Subtract operator should return Period
items.body:
```python
>>> import pendulum, datetime, sys
>>> sys.version
'2.7.15+ (default, Jul  9 2019, 16:51:35) \n[GCC 7.4.0]'
>>> pendulum.__version__
'2.0.5'
>>> datetime.datetime.now() - datetime.datetime.now()
datetime.timedelta(0)
>>> pendulum.now() - pendulum.now()
*** TypeError: TypeError("unsupported operand type(s) for -: 'DateTime' and 'DateTime'",)
```

To be a drop-in replacement, subtracting should probably call `diff()`?

items.title: ImportError: No module named wrapt
RecursionError when add or subtract-ing with a fixed offset timezone
items.body:
The following:
```
import pendulum
pendulum.datetime(2019, 11, 1, tz=pendulum.tz.fixed_timezone(0)).subtract(seconds=1)
```
```
import dateutil, pendulum
pendulum.datetime(2019, 11, 1, tz=dateutil.tz.tzoffset(name=None, offset=0)).subtract(seconds=1)
```
```
import aniso8601, pendulum
pendulum.datetime(2019, 11, 1, tz=aniso8601.utcoffset.UTCOffset(minutes=0)).subtract(seconds=1)
```
all result in this RecursionError:
```
  ....
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/pendulum/tz/timezone.py", line 66, in convert
    return self._convert(dt)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/pendulum/tz/timezone.py", line 334, in _convert
    return dt.astimezone(self)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/pendulum/datetime.py", line 1466, in astimezone
    return pendulum.instance(super(DateTime, self).astimezone(tz))
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/pendulum/tz/timezone.py", line 345, in fromutc
    return (dt + self._utcoffset).replace(tzinfo=self)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/pendulum/datetime.py", line 1442, in __add__
    return self._add_timedelta(other)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/pendulum/datetime.py", line 750, in _add_timedelta
    return self.add(seconds=delta.total_seconds())
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/pendulum/datetime.py", line 660, in add
    dt = self.tz.convert(dt)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/pendulum/tz/timezone.py", line 66, in convert
    return self._convert(dt)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/pendulum/tz/timezone.py", line 334, in _convert
    return dt.astimezone(self)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/pendulum/datetime.py", line 1466, in astimezone
    return pendulum.instance(super(DateTime, self).astimezone(tz))
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/pendulum/tz/timezone.py", line 345, in fromutc
    return (dt + self._utcoffset).replace(tzinfo=self)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/pendulum/datetime.py", line 1442, in __add__
    return self._add_timedelta(other)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/pendulum/datetime.py", line 750, in _add_timedelta
    return self.add(seconds=delta.total_seconds())
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/pendulum/datetime.py", line 621, in add
    offset = self.utcoffset()
RecursionError: maximum recursion depth exceeded
```

The actual date, offset, or number of seconds to add/subtract doesn't seem to matter, and using 'add' instead of subtract also causes the issue. A 'normal' timezone like 'Europe/London' won't cause the issue.

This came up with dates returned from our graphql API (which are parsed by graphene using aniso8601). Since all the fixed-offset tzinfo objects above trigger the same issue, I'm not sure what a good workaround would be, other than finding a 'normal' timezone that happens to have the same offset.

This is on CPython 3.8.0 on Linux, and I've tried with pendulum 2.0.4 and 2.0.5. I can't repro the issue on CPython 3.7.4, so I'm assuming it's 3.8-specific.

The closest existing issue I could find is https://github.com/sdispater/pendulum/issues/361 , but doesn't seem related - it's PyPy-specific, and `in_timezone` works okay on my example datetimes above.

items.title: Cannot check == between Period and timedelta
items.body:
Hello, I'm having trouble comparing the result of subtracting two DateTimes with a `timedelta`. If I run the following snippet:

```py
import pendulum
from pendulum.period import Period
from datetime import timedelta
d1 = pendulum.datetime(2019, 1, 2, tz='UTC')
d2 = pendulum.datetime(2019, 1, 1, tz='UTC')
period = d1 - d2
print(period == timedelta(days=1))
```

I get the following error, instead of the `True` I was expecting:

```
AttributeError: 'datetime.timedelta' object has no attribute 'start'
```

items.title: Subtracting negative timedelta around DST not same as adding the positive
items.body:
Hey! As I've been digging deeper into the Pendulum library, I've discovered one interesting edge-case: Namely that for specific times, subtracting a negative timedelta is not the same as adding the positive one.

Thus, `my_dt - my_negative_timedelta` is not equal to `my_dt + (-my_negative_timedelta)`.

As before, I took the liberty of throwing together what seemed a sensible patch: https://github.com/sdispater/pendulum/pull/419.

Here's also a pyfiddle, to see this in action: https://pyfiddle.io/fiddle/6a20e200-bb3a-4af9-b336-a216f868487d/.

Thanks!

items.title: `now('US/Pacific')` failing during DST transition
items.body:
I've been evaluating a few libraries to use for my company, and as I have a testing "rig" that can run our unit-test suite under arbitrary datetimes of the year, I've especially been digging into daylight savings transitions.

There was a couple of oddities I did discover. One was https://github.com/sdispater/pendulum/issues/415, but the other one is this: Calling `pendulum.now('US/Pacific')` yielded different results than `pendulum.now('UTC').in_tz('US/Pacific')`, latter yielding correct results.

So, running this at 2019-11-03 08:30:00+00:00 (set by system time, or using libfreezetime or freezegun):

```python
>>> now_utc_pt = pendulum.now('UTC').in_tz('US/Pacific')
>>> print(now_utc_pt.isoformat(), now_utc_pt.fold)
2019-11-03T01:30:00-07:00 0
>>> print(now_utc_pt.is_dst(), -now_utc_pt.utcoffset())
True 7:00:00
>>> now_pt = pendulum.now('US/Pacific')
>>> print(now_pt.isoformat(), now_pt.fold)
Conversely, let's ask directly for US/Pacific "now"
2019-11-03T01:30:00-08:00 1
>>> print(now_pt.is_dst(), -now_pt.utcoffset())
False 8:00:00
```

As with the other issue, I took the liberty to create a PR for a potential fix: https://github.com/sdispater/pendulum/pull/416.

Here's a small pyfiddle to showcase the behavior: https://pyfiddle.io/fiddle/f0ef4724-3af3-4e24-8a7c-254a17db9dec/?i=true

items.title: Bad results using .replace() during DST transitioning off
items.body:
Hi sdispater!

First of all - thanks for this library - my company started out with arrow because it seemed easy etc.. But man, are there drawbacks... Pendulum seems to be doing things the right way, so thanks a lot for crafting this.

Now - I've been digging fairly deep into DST transitions recently, and I think I may have discovered 2 small bugs. To start with, I'll start with the (hopefully) more straight-forward one here (the other is https://github.com/sdispater/pendulum/issues/417).

Seems that if one has a datetime in the hour after DST transitions off, and then does a `.replace(seconds=0)`, it messes up the DST information on the `DateTime` object.

```python
>>> # Daylight savings turning off for US/Pacific in 2019 
>>> # happenes on the 3rd of November, at 9:00 UTC
>>> dt = pendulum.datetime(2019, 11, 3, 8, 30, 12)
>>> tz = pendulum.timezone('US/Pacific')
>>> dtz = tz.convert(dt)
>>> print(dtz.isoformat())
2019-11-03T01:30:12-07:00
>>> print(dtz.fold, dtz.is_dst(), -dtz.utcoffset())
0 True 7:00:00

>>> dtz2 = dtz.replace(second=0)
>>> print(dtz2.isoformat())
2019-11-03T01:30:00-08:00
>>> print(dtz2.fold, dtz2.is_dst(), -dtz2.utcoffset())
1 False 8:00:00
```

I took the liberty of trying my hand at a fix: https://github.com/sdispater/pendulum/pull/414.

I set up a small pyfiddle showcasing the behavior: https://pyfiddle.io/fiddle/d80564bc-96ca-4fe8-9e3e-982a474e9e73/?i=true

```
>>> pendulum.parse('2000-07-01T09:30+0000').in_timezone('Africa/Casablanca').isoformat()
'2000-07-01T09:30:00+00:00'
>>> pendulum.parse('2000-01-01T09:30+0000').in_timezone('Africa/Casablanca').isoformat()
'2000-01-01T09:30:00+00:00'
```
I have installed pendulum today (23 Aug) using pip in a macos and this is the installed version :
```
>>> print(pendulum.__version__)
2.0.5
```
I read that the issue was resolved in this ticket but it's not clear for me in which version specially that I have just installed pendulum today : https://github.com/sdispater/pendulum/issues/370

Thank you

items.title: Cannot parse 'Z' timezone using `from_format`
items.body:
The RFC3339 format (`YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ssZ`) can't be used to parse conformant date/times with `Z` as the timezone (for example "2019-01-01T12:00:00Z"):

```
$ poetry run python
>>> import pendulum
>>> from pendulum.formatting import Formatter
>>> from pendulum.constants import RFC3339
>>> Formatter().parse("2019-01-01T12:00:00Z", RFC3339, pendulum.now())
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/bl/work/ap/ap-data/hoover/.venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pendulum/formatting/formatter.py", line 409, in parse
    re.sub(pattern, lambda m: self._get_parsed_values(m, parsed, locale, now), time)
  File "/opt/python/3.7.2/lib/python3.7/re.py", line 192, in sub
    return _compile(pattern, flags).sub(repl, string, count)
  File "/home/bl/work/ap/ap-data/hoover/.venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pendulum/formatting/formatter.py", line 409, in <lambda>
    re.sub(pattern, lambda m: self._get_parsed_values(m, parsed, locale, now), time)
  File "/home/bl/work/ap/ap-data/hoover/.venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pendulum/formatting/formatter.py", line 538, in _get_parsed_values
    self._get_parsed_value(token, m.group(index), parsed, now)
  File "/home/bl/work/ap/ap-data/hoover/.venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pendulum/formatting/formatter.py", line 587, in _get_parsed_value
    offset = ((int(off_hour) * 60) + int(off_minute)) * 60
ValueError: invalid literal for int() with base 10: ''
```

It works fine if I replace with `+00:00`:
```
>>> Formatter().parse("2019-01-01T12:00:00+00:00", RFC3339, pendulum.now())
{'year': 2019, 'month': 1, 'day': 1, 'hour': 12, 'minute': 0, 'second': 0, 'microsecond': 0, 'tz': Timezone('+00:00')}
```

items.title: 'utf-8' codec can't decode byte 0xe9 in position 185: invalid continuation byte
items.body: Current version does not install on Windows. Has been confirmed several times by multiple people. See here: https://github.com/pypa/pip/issues/6566

items.title: Support negative ISO 8601 dates
items.body:
It seems that Pendulum cannot parse dates from BCE, ex `pendulum.parse('-0100-07-12')`, throwing a `ParserError` instead.

According to [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601#Years), in these cases the year should have a `-` prefix. I couldn't find any alternative syntax for Pendulum, either.

items.title: Typo in formatting.formatter._MATCH_TIMEZONE (A-z -> A-Z)
items.body:
https://github.com/sdispater/pendulum/blob/94d28b0d3cb524ae02361bd1ed7ea03e2e655e4e/pendulum/formatting/formatter.py#L36

Should be `A-Z` not `A-z`.  The latter accepts a few characters such a `[`.

items.title: Extra text allowed after matching time with from_format()
items.body:
`re.match()` doesn't anchor to the end of the string thus allowing extra text without an error.

items.title: Daylight savings time
items.body:
Came across this when looking at the examples. Not sure if it's a bug or that I'm just misunderstanding the logic:

```
>>> print(pendulum.datetime(2013, 3, 31, 2, 30, tz="UTC"))
2013-03-31T02:30:00+00:00 #all good
>>> print(pendulum.datetime(2013, 3, 31, 2, 30, tz="Europe/Paris"))
2013-03-31T03:30:00+02:00 #why 3:30??
>>> print(pendulum.datetime(2013, 3, 1, 2, 30, tz="Europe/Paris"))
2013-03-01T02:30:00+01:00 # this makes sense again
>>> print(pendulum.datetime(2013, 4, 1, 2, 30, tz="Europe/Paris"))
2013-04-01T02:30:00+02:00 # this also makes sense
```
In all of the cases I would expect the time to be 2:30, but in the second example it is actually 3:30. What am I missing here? It shows the same issue in your documentation (under Fluent helpers). It seems to have something to do with daylight savings (the second is just past DST (ends at 2:00 in Paris), third is not DST, fourth is DST).

items.title: duration.as_timedelta() ignores years and months
items.body:
Currently, `pendulum` claims:

> durations support specifying years and months.
> native methods and properties will make approximations

The following public method, to me, appears to break this promise:

```
import datetime, pendulum
d = pendulum.duration(years=1, months=2)
assert d.as_timedelta() == datetime.timedelta(0)
```

This is unexpected. I would approximate `d == datetime.timedelta(days=365 + 2*30)`. What is the preferred way of at casting `d` to a native `timedelta`?

items.title: Fourth Thursday of November
items.body:
[Thanksgiving in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thanksgiving_(United_States)) is on the fourth Thursday of November.

```python
In [78]: ( 
    ...:     pendulum.parse('2020') 
    ...:     .set(month=10) 
    ...:     .end_of('month') 
    ...:     .next(pendulum.THURSDAY) 
    ...:     .next(pendulum.THURSDAY) 
    ...:     .next(pendulum.THURSDAY) 
    ...:     .next(pendulum.THURSDAY) 
    ...: )     
DateTime(2020, 11, 26, 0, 0, 0, tzinfo=Timezone('UTC'))

```

Is there a better way to calculate that date?

items.title: Wrong value returned from offset for timezones in Brazil
items.body:
At this time, Brazil is using Daylight Savings Time, and Pendulum is not taking this into account when you want to get the difference between local time and UTC time.

```
Python 3.6.5 (default, Apr  1 2018, 05:46:30) 
[GCC 7.3.0] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import datetime, pytz, pendulum
>>> pendulum.from_timestamp(0, 'America/Sao_Paulo').offset/60/60
-3.0
>>> datetime.datetime.now(pytz.timezone('America/Sao_Paulo')).utcoffset().total_seconds()/60/60
-2.0
```
The correct value is -2.00. -3.00 is the difference when DST is not in use.

Curiously, only the **offset** appears to have this behavior:

```
>>> pendulum.now().in_timezone('America/Sao_Paulo')
DateTime(2018, 11, 29, 18, 16, 12, 155483, tzinfo=Timezone('America/Sao_Paulo'))
>>> pendulum.now().in_timezone('America/Sao_Paulo').to_iso8601_string()
'2018-11-29T18:16:30.730995-02:00'
```
Is this a bug or am I not correctly understanding the use of **offset**?

items.title: Representing old dates
items.body:
From https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Year_zero#ISO_8601,

> The "basic" format for year 0 is the four-digit form 0000, which equals the historical year 1 BC.

```python
>>> import pendulum
>>> pendulum.__version__
'2.0.3'
>>> pendulum.from_format('0000-01-01', 'YYYY-MM-DD')
ValueError: year 0 is out of range
```

This came up because [Matlab uses](https://www.mathworks.com/help/matlab/ref/datenum.html) "A serial date number represents the whole and fractional number of days from a fixed, preset date (January 0, 0000) in the proleptic ISO calendar."

Apparently [Astropy can handle](https://stackoverflow.com/a/19869864/3346095) old dates, as can [jdcal](https://pypi.org/project/jdcal/).

items.title: [Question] from_format with tz='UTC' on string with explicit offset, the tz='UTC' gets dropped.
items.body:
I want to make sure this is done on purpose because I am now writing code that depends on this behavior.

I have a string like `'2018-07-28 00:00:00-07:00'` and format `YYYY-MM-DD HH:mm:ssZ` but I also give `from_format` a `tz='UTC'` argument. The resulting `DateTime` has seemingly ignored that I passed a timezone and favors the offset defined in the string.

Is this the intended API? If so, I'm curious to learn more about the reasons behind this decision.
I ask because I am currently writing code based on this being intentional and not changing in the future.

```python
Python 3.6.5 (default, Apr 25 2018, 14:23:58) 
[GCC 4.2.1 Compatible Apple LLVM 9.1.0 (clang-902.0.39.1)] on darwin
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> from pendulum import from_format, parse
>>> dt = from_format('2018-07-28 00:00:00-07:00', 'YYYY-MM-DD HH:mm:ssZ', tz='UTC')
>>> dt
DateTime(2018, 7, 28, 0, 0, 0, tzinfo=Timezone('-07:00'))
>>> 
```

The code I am writing is trying to catch when my program has encountered a string that has an explicit offset, but was expecting the string to be ambiguous so it could apply a fixed offset to it.

```python
def safe_from_format(dt_str, fmt, tz_name='UTC'):
    try:
        return from_format(dt_str, fmt, tz=tz_name)
    except ValueError:
        # If the above fails, sometimes this works
        # Pendulum bug: https://github.com/sdispater/pendulum/issues/266
        return parse(dt_str, tz=tz_name)

def from_vague_str_with_utc_offset(dt_str, fmt, utc_offset):
    dt = safe_from_format(dt_str, fmt)
    if dt.timezone_name != 'UTC':
        # If the datetime doesn't have a timezone set to UTC, it means the dt_str
        # explicitly defines it's offset. If we were to apply our fixed offset now
        # we would be double applying an offset.
        # This is caused by a bad answer to datetime questions and should fail.
        raise ValueError('Attempting to apply offset to timestamp with an explicit offset')
    return dt - duration(hours=utc_offset)
```

Thanks for any insights!

items.title: Space-padded days in from_format
items.body:
First off, thanks for this great library – I’m basically using it in all of my projects. Now I’ve run into a format oddity that seems to be more common than I thought: space-padded days.

This is used by `ls`, OpenSSL, and apparently syslog.

For example what I needed to parse today is `Apr  2 12:00:00 2020 GMT` (note the two spaces before the first 2) which requires a different from_format format than say `Apr 12 12:00:00 2020 GMT`. 

It looks like datetime's strptime [handles this](https://twitter.com/moreati/status/969329950925967361) out of the box.  True to pendulum's principles I would of course prefer an explicit way of saying “space-padded day” instead of guessing.

items.title: Incorrect `age` calculation for future dates.
items.body:
```python
import pendulum
birthday = pendulum.parse('9999-12-31')
birthday.age < 16
```
```
Out[5]: False
```

pendulum==2.0.3
python3.5.4

The problem is that underlying `pendulum.Date.diff` returns absolute value in years. While it looks it should be non absolute value.

```
@property
def age(self):
    return self.date().diff(self.now(self.tz).date()).in_years()
```

So I suppose that passing `abs=False` parameter to the `pendulum.Date.diff` would fix the issue.

items.title: v2 cannot parse standard US MM/DD/YYYY format
items.body: The docs state "The library natively supports the RFC 3339 format, most ISO 8601 formats **and some other common formats**." Yet it cannot parse the standard MM/DD/YYYY (i.e. today is 07/16/2018) format as commonly used in the USA. More annoyingly, this format previously worked with v1 causing unexpected breakages upon upgrade.  Sure you can use .from_format(input_string, 'MM/DD/YYYY') but that defeats the purpose of having a parser that'll _generally_ work if you feed it a reasonable string.

items.title: A suggestion for the Period class - constraints on the Period class creation
items.body:
A suggestion for the Period class.
The abilty to somehow set some constraints on the Period class creation
eg.
- min_start, max_start
- min_end, max_end
- min_duration , max_duration

As api's go I really dont know what the best approach here is. But it does seem like normally you want to control Periods to some sort of sane values that makes sense to the contex of your application (I know I want to). Also to me it seems like a nice place to have that logic.

Maybe nothing should be done and the best way is to subclass Period as I tried below. Or if worked into the api maybe could be kwargs or another class constructor etc...

Anyway, just a suggestion.


```python
import pendulum

class PeriodSanityError(ValueError):
    pass

class MyPeriod(pendulum.Period):
    _min_start = None
    _max_start = None

    def __init__(self, start, end):
        super().__init__(start=start, end=end)

        # could do this before the calling super
        self._sanity_check()

    def _sanity_check(self):
        if self._min_start:
            if self.start < self._min_start:
                raise PeriodSanityError('min start error...Blah Blah....')
        if self._max_start:
            if self.start > self._max_start:
                raise PeriodSanityError('max start error...Blah Blah....')


if __name__ == '__main__':
    # use class vars to set the constraints
    MyPeriod._min_start = pendulum.today()
    MyPeriod._max_start = pendulum.today().add(years=1)

    today = pendulum.today()
    yesterday = today.subtract(days=1)
    end = today.add(days=5)

    p = MyPeriod(today, end)

    # will raise a PeriodSanityError
    p2 = MyPeriod(yesterday, end)           # start to early
    p3 = MyPeriod(today.add(years=2), end)  # start to late
```

Here is the code that was used to generate that output:
```
# This test shows failure with a custom build of Python 3.6 based on image - FROM phusion/baseimage

import re
import platform


def thisWorks(argString):
	print("thisWorks")
	reDate = re.compile("(?P<MONTH>\d+)/(?P<DAY>\d+)/(?P<YEAR>\d+)", re.IGNORECASE)
	reObjSearch = reDate.search(dateString)

	if reObjSearch:
		month = int(reObjSearch.group('MONTH'))
		day = int(reObjSearch.group('DAY'))
		year = int(reObjSearch.group('YEAR'))

	print(pendulum.datetime(year, month, day))


def thisDoesNotWork(argString):
	print("thisDoesNotWork")
	reDate = re.compile("(?P<MONTH>\d+)/(?P<DAY>\d+)/(?P<YEAR>\d+)", re.IGNORECASE)
	reObjSearch = reDate.search(dateString)

	if reObjSearch:
		month = int(reObjSearch.group('MONTH'))
		day = int(reObjSearch.group('DAY'))
		year = int(reObjSearch.group('YEAR'))

	print(pendulum.datetime(year, month, day, tzinfo='US/Central'))


def thisAlsoDoesNotWork(argString):
	print("thisAlsoDoesNotWork")
	reDate = re.compile("(?P<DATE>\d+/\d+/\d+)", re.IGNORECASE)
	reObjSearch = reDate.search(dateString)

	if reObjSearch:
		date = reObjSearch.group('DATE')

	print(pendulum.parse(date))


def printDebugInfo():
	print(f"'system               :', {platform.system()}")
	print(f"'release              :', {platform.release()}")
	print(f"'version              :', {platform.version()}")
	print(f"'machine              :', {platform.machine()}")
	print(f"'processor            :', {platform.processor()}")
	print(f"'python_build         :' {platform.python_build()}")
	print(f"'python_compiler      :' {platform.python_compiler()}")
	print(f"'python_version       :' {platform.python_version()}")
	print(f"'python_implementation:' {platform.python_implementation()}\n\n")


dateString = '''07/03/2018):
Balance (last updated
$999.99'''

printDebugInfo()

try:
	thisWorks(dateString)

except Exception as e:
	print(str(e))

try:
	thisDoesNotWork(dateString)

except Exception as e:
	print(str(e))

try:
	thisAlsoDoesNotWork(dateString)

except Exception as e:
	print(str(e))
```

Would it be possible to add the `nanosecond` attribute to `DateTime` class, event if it always returns 0 for now?

```python
import pendulum
from libfaketime import fake_time, reexec_if_needed

reexec_if_needed()

```

Executing it crashes with the following stacktrace:
```
$ python ttt.py
re-exec with libfaketime dependencies

  File "/mnt/f/projects/parsec-cloud/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pendulum/tz/zoneinfo/reader.py", line 48, in read_for

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

    return get_local_timezone()
  File "/mnt/f/projects/parsec-cloud/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pendulum/tz/local_timezone.py", line 31, in get_local_timezone

    return _tz_from_env(tzenv)
  File "/mnt/f/projects/parsec-cloud/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pendulum/tz/local_timezone.py", line 251, in _tz_from_env
```

items.body:
I believe this issue is related to #167 
On Windows 10 WSL (linux subsystem) with pendulum 2.0.2

```python
>>> import pendulum
>>> from copy import deepcopy
>>> pendulum.local_timezone()
Timezone('')
>>> from pendulum.tz.local_timezone import _get_unix_timezone
>>> _get_unix_timezone()
Timezone('')
>>> pendulum.now().tzinfo
Timezone('')
>>> deepcopy(pendulum.now())
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/mnt/f/projects/parsec-cloud/venv/lib/python3.6/copy.py", line 180, in deepcopy
    y = _reconstruct(x, memo, *rv)
  File "/mnt/f/projects/parsec-cloud/venv/lib/python3.6/copy.py", line 274, in _reconstruct
    y = func(*args)
  File "/mnt/f/projects/parsec-cloud/venv/lib/python3.6/copy.py", line 273, in <genexpr>
    args = (deepcopy(arg, memo) for arg in args)
  File "/mnt/f/projects/parsec-cloud/venv/lib/python3.6/copy.py", line 180, in deepcopy
    y = _reconstruct(x, memo, *rv)
  File "/mnt/f/projects/parsec-cloud/venv/lib/python3.6/copy.py", line 274, in _reconstruct
    y = func(*args)
  File "/mnt/f/projects/parsec-cloud/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pendulum/tz/timezone.py", line 379, in __init__
    tz = read_file(path)
  File "/mnt/f/projects/parsec-cloud/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pendulum/tz/zoneinfo/__init__.py", line 16, in read_file
    return Reader(extend=extend).read(path)
  File "/mnt/f/projects/parsec-cloud/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pendulum/tz/zoneinfo/reader.py", line 61, in read
    raise InvalidZoneinfoFile('The tzinfo file does not exist')
pendulum.tz.zoneinfo.exceptions.InvalidZoneinfoFile: The tzinfo file does not exist
```

From what I understood, the trouble comes from the fact the Timezone object comes from a `TimezoneFile`:
https://github.com/sdispater/pendulum/blob/3698fcbe39a42d5df8147e1ddc06160fe03ed000/pendulum/tz/local_timezone.py#L230-L236

However `TimezoneFile` sets it name to an empty string:
https://github.com/sdispater/pendulum/blob/3698fcbe39a42d5df8147e1ddc06160fe03ed000/pendulum/tz/timezone.py#L376-L386

I guess the fix could be to keep more information when parsing the local timezone file (https://github.com/sdispater/pendulum/blob/3698fcbe39a42d5df8147e1ddc06160fe03ed000/pendulum/tz/zoneinfo/reader.py#L86).
(btw I find very confusing to have two unrelated-but-working-together `pendulum.tz.timezone.Timezone` and `pendulum.tz.zoneinfo.Timezone`...)

items.title: Different behaviour when using tz in constructor or astimezone later
items.body:
See https://stackoverflow.com/a/50444600/562769 for context

## Case 1: Expected behaviour

```
from pendulum import datetime
from datetime import timedelta
import pytz

t11 = datetime(1918, 4, 15, 0, 0).astimezone(pytz.timezone('Europe/Berlin'))
t12 = t11 + timedelta(hours=1)
```
gives:

```
t11: 1918-04-15T01:00:00+01:00
t12: 1918-04-15T03:00:00+02:00
```

## Case 2: Unexpected behaviour

```
from pendulum import datetime
from datetime import timedelta
import pytz

t11 = datetime(1918, 4, 15, 0, 0, tz='Europe/Berlin')
t12 = t11 + timedelta(hours=1)
```

gives:

```
t11: 1918-04-15T00:00:00+01:00
t12: 1918-04-15T01:00:00+01:00
```

items.title: PendulumException should derive from Exception instead of BaseException
items.body:
Hi,

as is stated in the [official documentation](https://docs.python.org/3/library/exceptions.html):
> programmers are encouraged to derive new exceptions from the Exception class or one of its subclasses, and not from BaseException

The rational is discussed in [PEP352](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0352/) or this [StackOverflow discussion](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/27995057/why-is-it-recommended-to-derive-from-exception-instead-of-baseexception-class-in).

Moreover, I think most programmers (at least me!) expect that all errors are caught in a `except Exception` block, which is currently not the case, you have to:

    except (Exception, pendulum.exceptions.PendulumException):

to be sure to catch everything but the system exit, keyboard interrupt...
Perhaps it's still time for v2 ?

Best regards and thanks for the amazing library!

items.title: pendulum.replace does not correctly set tzinfo
items.body:
Using pendulum 1.5.1, I get an `IndexError: list index out of range` exception using the following code

```python
import croniter
import pendulum
import datetime
croniter.croniter('0 0 * * *', pendulum.today(tz=pendulum.UTC)).get_next(datetime.datetime)
```

After some debugging, I think the following line in the `replace` method is causing the error:
https://github.com/sdispater/pendulum/blob/41f5ac3c145b66dbf5c2f1d9c6860a8c776a09f2/pendulum/pendulum.py#L2132

Replacing `tzinfo = self._tzinfo.tz` with `tzinfo = self._tzinfo` fixes it.

_First one (Windows)_


I guess this is somehow related to C extensions, because `from pendulum.parsing._iso8601 import parse_iso8601` raises a `ModuleNotFound` exception on my Windows, but not on Linux.

On the other hand, `from pendulum._extensions._helpers import local_time` works fine on both Linux and Windows, so it confuses me a little bit... 😕

items.title: Bug: start_of('month') doesn't zero microseconds
items.body:
`start_of('day')` works as expected but `start_of('month')` seems to keep the microseconds from the original date.

```python
In [21]: now
Out[21]: DateTime(2018, 5, 14, 9, 57, 34, 910558, tzinfo=Timezone('America/Santiago'))

In [22]: now.start_of('month')
Out[22]: DateTime(2018, 5, 1, 0, 0, 0, 910558, tzinfo=Timezone('America/Santiago'))

In [23]: now.start_of('day')
Out[23]: DateTime(2018, 5, 14, 0, 0, 0, tzinfo=Timezone('America/Santiago'))
```

Update: It looks like it's due to a `0` microsecond argument missing from [here](https://github.com/sdispater/pendulum/blob/9c588843e8f0747ba30e06e34b394a6dd2284335/pendulum/datetime.py#L863). It looks like it also affects start of `year`, `decade`, `century`...

items.title: Period has no __hash__ or __eq__ which makes the behavior of set() highly confusing
items.body:
Any set of periods that has the same duration are seen as equal. This is highly confusing and decreases the usefulness of Period.

See the below code example:
```python
import pendulum
period1 = pendulum.DateTime(2018, 1, 3) - pendulum.DateTime(2018, 1, 2)
period2 = pendulum.DateTime(2018, 1, 2) - pendulum.DateTime(2018, 1, 1)
s = {period1, period2}
assert len(s) == 1  # 2 would be the expected result
```

items.title: Change in default millennium in from_format in 2.x?
items.body:
In 2.x I gather that `from_format` now needs to use the former "alternative" formatting, so I changed my code. I was surprised to find that a date previously parsed as 2018 now is parsed as 1918.

Pendulum 1.5.1:
```
>>> pendulum.from_format('02/13/18 15:00', '%m/%d/%y %H:%M')
<Pendulum [2018-02-13T15:00:00+00:00]>
```

Pendulum 2.0.0:
```
>>> pendulum.from_format('02/13/18 15:00', 'MM/DD/YY HH:mm')
DateTime(1918, 2, 13, 15, 0, 0, tzinfo=Timezone('UTC'))
```

Is this intentional? If so, it seems like an odd default.

items.body:
The following happens on Amazon Linux AMI release 2018.03 with pendulum 2.0.0 (but also with 1.5.1):

    Python 3.4.8 (default, Apr 25 2018, 23:50:36)
    [GCC 4.8.5 20150623 (Red Hat 4.8.5-11)] on linux
    Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
    >>> from pendulum.tz.local_timezone import _get_unix_timezone
    >>> _get_unix_timezone()
    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "/home/dmitrii/.local/lib/python3.4/site-packages/pendulum/tz/zoneinfo/reader.py", line 49, in read_for
        file_path = pytzdata.tz_path(timezone)
      File "/usr/local/lib/python3.4/site-packages/pytzdata/__init__.py", line 74, in tz_path
        raise TimezoneNotFound('Timezone {} not found at {}'.format(name, filepath))
    pytzdata.exceptions.TimezoneNotFound: Timezone /usr/share/zoneinfo/Europe/Zurich not found at /usr/local/lib/python3.4/site-packages/pytzdata/zoneinfo/usr/share/zoneinfo/Europe/Zurich

    During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
      File "/home/dmitrii/.local/lib/python3.4/site-packages/pendulum/tz/local_timezone.py", line 206, in _get_unix_timezone
        return Timezone(etctz.replace(' ', '_'))
      File "/home/dmitrii/.local/lib/python3.4/site-packages/pendulum/tz/timezone.py", line 30, in __init__
        tz = read(name, extend=extended)
      File "/home/dmitrii/.local/lib/python3.4/site-packages/pendulum/tz/zoneinfo/__init__.py", line 9, in read

The documentation says:

After getting the deprecaton warning about the `timezone_` method, I tried to change to using `set`. Following the documentation ends up with this error:

items.title: UTC indicator should be Z not +00:00 in ISO8601 strings
items.body:
From the ISO 8601 specification:

> The zone designator is empty if use is made of local time in accordance with 4.2.2.2 through 4.2.2.4, it is the UTC designator [Z] if use is made of UTC of day in accordance with 4.2.4 and it is the difference-component if use is made of local time and the difference from UTC in accordance with 4.2.5.2.

From this text, I infer that you are not supposed to use "+00:00" to indicate UTC time.

Pendulum should use the Z indicator instead of +00:00:

```
>>> pendulum.utcnow().to_iso8601_string()
'2018-04-17T11:30:08+00:00'
```

items.title: Use setuptools again
items.body:
I'm packaging this software in [AUR](https://aur.archlinux.org/packages/python-pendulum/) for Arch Linux. Support for setuptools was dropped with commit 3c0bdcbabce38e4e809fb9ccc7a12e3210eadead, in favour of poetry. While I can understand that you want to push your own package standard, I can attest to the fact that packaging your software differently than anyone else, is a headache for distribution packagers. Basically I cannot package your software anymore without getting into `poetry`.

In the poetry README you state:

    The package is highly experimental at the moment so expect things to change and break.

That sound's crazy to me. Isn't it possible to support both of them in parallel?

items.title: Pendulum.astimezone crashes with dateutil.tz.tzlocal
items.body:
Using pendulum 1.4.2 and 2.7.0:

```python
(venv) >>> import pendulum
(venv) >>> dt = pendulum.now()
(venv) >>> import dateutil
(venv) >>> dt.astimezone(dateutil.tz.tzlocal())
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/emmanuel/projects/sief-back/venv/lib/python3.5/site-packages/pendulum/pendulum.py", line 1960, in astimezone
    tz = self._safe_create_datetime_zone(tz)
  File "/home/emmanuel/projects/sief-back/venv/lib/python3.5/site-packages/pendulum/pendulum.py", line 80, in _safe_create_datetime_zone
    return FixedTimezone.load(obj.utcoffset(None).total_seconds())
AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'total_seconds'
```

I've fixed this crash by monkeypatching `Pendulum._safe_create_datetime_zone`:
```python
@classmethod
def patched_Pendulum_safe_create_datetime_zone(cls, obj):
    if isinstance(obj, tzlocal):
        obj = None
    return cls._vanilla_safe_create_datetime_zone(obj)

Pendulum._vanilla_safe_create_datetime_zone = Pendulum._safe_create_datetime_zone
Pendulum._safe_create_datetime_zone = patched_Pendulum_safe_create_datetime_zone
```

I can provide a PR if you think this is the correct way to address this bug ;-)

items.title: Incorrect handling of time differences with timezones in version 1.4.2
items.body:
Under version 1.4.1 the following tests pass, under 1.4.2 only the one without timezones does.

`tests/period_tests/test_add_subtract.py`
```
def test_period_over_midnight_no_tz():
    start = pendulum.create(2018, 2, 25, 23, 0)
    end = start.add(hours=1)
    period = end - start
    new_end = start + period

    assert new_end == end

def test_period_over_midnight_tz():
    start = pendulum.create(2018, 2, 25, tz='Europe/Paris')
    end = start.add(hours=1)
    period = end - start
    new_end = start + period

    assert new_end == end
```

The change that introduced this behavior is here: https://github.com/sdispater/pendulum/commit/5b06241f07ade260cb8825e7394890f2e4937b9c#diff-33c1eb0997d2cda44f837c4ede470d7cR200
